Input1: A $3\,\mathrm{V}$ battery is connected to a $6\,\Omega$ resistor. How many electrons pass each second? ($e=1.6\times 10^{-19}\,\mathrm{C}$)
 ----- Reference Model ----- Reference Response: The current is given by $I=\frac{V}{R}$, where $V$ is the voltage and $R$ is the resistance. The current is the rate of flow of charge, so the number of electrons per second is $I\cdot t$, where $t$ is the time in seconds. The charge on an electron is $e=1.6\times 10^{-19}\,\mathrm{C}$, so the number of electrons is $I\cdot t\cdot \frac{1}{e}$. The current is $I=\frac{3\,\mathrm{V}}{6\,\Omega}=0.5\,\mathrm{A}$, so the number of electrons per second is $0.5\,\mathrm{A}\cdot 1\,\mathrm{s}\cdot \frac{1}{1.6\times 10^{-19}\,\mathrm{C}}=3.1\times 10^{18}\,\mathrm{electrons}$.
 ----- Policy Model ----- Policy Response: Step 1:';
